Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, follow the directions in the GNOME Feedback Page.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables you to search for files on your system. To perform a basic search, you can type a filename or a partial filename with wildcards. To refine your search, you can select additional search options that you want &app; to apply.
&app; uses the find, grep, and locate UNIX commands.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:
When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

sect2.title: To Perform a Basic Search
sect2.para: To perform a basic search for a file on the system, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the File is named field, enter one of the following strings:
A full filename, for example myfile.txt. &app; searches for all files on the system named myfile.txt.
A partial filename combined with wildcards (*), for example *.txt. &app; searches the filesystem for all files with the extension .txt.
In the Look in folder field enter the path to the directory in which you want &app; to begin the search. &app; searches in the directory that you specify and the subdirectories of the directory.

Click Find to perform the search. &app; displays the results of the search in the Search Results list box. If &app; does not find any files that match the search criteria, the application displays the message "No Files Found" in the Search Results list box.

sect2.title: To Add Search Options
sect2.para: To add search options to search for a file on the system, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click the Available options drop-down list box.
Select the search option that you want to apply.
Click Add to add the search option to the list of additional options.
Specify the required search information for the search rule, see for information.
Repeat the above steps for each search option that you want to apply.

sect2.para: To remove a search option from the Additional Options list, click on the Remove button next to the option.

entry.para: Search for files that contain specific text. The search is case sensitive.
Search for files that were modified in the period less than the number of days specified.
Search for files that were modified in the period more than the number of days specified.
Search for files that are larger than the size specified.
Search for files that are less than the size specified.
Search for files that are owned by the user specified. Type the name of the user in the text box provided.
Search for files that are owned by the group specified. Type the name of the group in the text box provided.
Search for files that are owned by a user or group that is unknown to the system.

Search for files that do not match the filename that you enter. Enter a full filename or a partial filename with wildcards in the field provided. Use * to indicate a sequence of characters. Use ? to indicate a single character. The search is case sensitive.
Search for files that contain the specified regular expression in their directory path or filename. Type the regular expression in the text box provided.
Follow symbolic links when searching for files.
Search includes directories that are not in the same filesystem as the start directory.

sect2.title: To Stop a Search
sect2.para: Click Stop to stop a search before &app; completes the search.

sect2.title: To Open a File Found
sect2.para: To open a file displayed in the Search Results list box, perform one of the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the file, then choose Open.

sect2.para: To open the folder that contains a file displayed in the Search Results list box, right-click on the file, then choose Open Folder.
To copy a file displayed in the Search Results list box to another area on the desktop, drag the file to the area.

sect2.title: To Save the Search Results
sect2.para: To save the results of the last search that &app; performed, right-click in the Search Results list, then choose Save Results As. Enter the name of the file to which you want to save the results, then click OK.
